Section 1    Executive Summary

The Water & Sewer Board of the City of Wetumpka developed a Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) to be implemented at the Wilako Wastewater Treatment Plant in an effort to protect human health, to protect the environment and meet applicable federal regulations.  This plant is operated by the Water & Sewer Board and has a capacity to process 4.5 million gallons of domestic waste per day.  It is located in Section 22, Township 18 North, Range 18 East, just south of Alabama Highway 14 approximately two and < miles west of the downtown Wetumpka area.  The plant address is 2909 Elmore Road, Wetumpka, Elmore County, Alabama.

This RMPlan has been developed to meet the standards published in the 40 Code of Federal Register (CFR) part 6

8.  These regulations were promulgated by the EPA to cover the accidental release prevention provision under the Clean Air Act '112(r)(7).  These require facilities that exceed the cited threshold quantities for certain chemicals to develop a RMPlan.  The goal of a RMPlan is to focus on reducing the risk of accidental releases of certain chemicals; thereby, preventing harm to employees as well as potentially catastrophic impacts on the public.  Over 60 accidental releases of RMPlan regulated chemicals at waste treatment plants (WTP's) and wastewater treatment facilities in the United States were reported between 1986 and 1995. 

The chemicals currently used in the wastewater process at this site that are covered by the regulation include chlorine and anhydrous ammonia, although the anhydrous ammonia threshold is greater than the amount stored on site.  It is also anticipated that sulfur dioxide (another covered chemical under the standard) will be added to the process in the near future.  The maximum potential amount of chlorine to be present on site at any one time is 8,000 pounds, and 4,500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Chlorine is stored in one ton cylinders, and although there is potential for 8,000 pounds to be present on the site at any one time, typically, at least on of the cylinders is empty so usually less than 6,000 pounds is on site.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 1,000-gallon above ground storage tanks.  It is anticipated that one-ton sulfur dioxide cylinders will be used in the process.  A maximum of 4,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide is anticipated to be stored on site.

In order to illustrate the areas that could be impacted from a release of the chemicals into the atmosphere, offsite consequence analyses were conducted.  Two offsite consequence analyses were performed for each of the chemicals of concern.  The first release scenario is the case defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as the "worst case" scenario.  This scenario assumes t

hat the largest vessel of each chemical is full and it releases the entire contents of the containers during a ten-minute period.  The second scenario (or alternative scenario) is based on a situation more likely to occur which will cause a release of chemicals at the facility.  The radius of impact was determined based on the guidance provided in Chapter 4: "Offsite Consequence Analysis" of the General Guidance for Risk Management Programs dated October 27, 1998.
In all release scenarios, the toxic end point concentration remains the same.  The toxic end point for chlorine and sulfur dioxide is three parts per million (ppm), and is 200 ppm for anhydrous ammonia.  The American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) has listed these concentrations as the "maximum airborne concentration", at which nearly all individuals could be exposed to for up to one hour without experiencing or developing life threatening health effects.  Results of the off-site consequence analyses for the EPA "worst case" scenario led to an area defined by a 3-mile radius for chlorine, a 3.0- mile radius for sulfur dioxide, and a 1.2- mile radius for anhydrous ammonia.  These three-mile radii encompass the majority of the Wetumpka Incorporated area that includes a population of approximately 4,000 people (according to 1990 census data).  The alternative off-site consequence analysis yields significantly smaller areas.  The off-site analysis for chlorine indicates a 1.4-mile radius to the end point concentration, a sulfur dioxide area of 0.9-mile radius, and an anhydrous ammonia area of 0.4- mile radius. 

The key to a successful risk management program is to first define hazard, risk and undertake a comprehensive approach to prevention.  The Center for Chemical Process Safety has defined hazard as:

A chemical or physical condition that has the potential for causing damage to people, property or the environment 

Once hazards are identified on the site, then, an evaluation of the risk involved wi

ll lead to a systematic identification, evaluation, and control of potential losses that may arise in operation from future events such as fires, explosions, or toxic chemical releases.  The Water & Sewer Board has previously developed and implemented a safety program for the Wilako Wastewater Treatment Plant and this program is to become an integral part of this RMPlan to achieve the highest standards of safety and preparedness.  The safety program sets forth inspections and maintenance requirements of equipment, employees training and periodically reviewing readiness.  Throughout this RMPlan, the emergency readiness procedures and regular training schedules are emphasized.  One of the goals of implementing these procedures and schedules is to minimize the chance of a release occurring.  If the plant employees practice preventative maintenance and are well trained in emergency procedures, if a release occurs, they will be successful in preventing and minimizing personnel injury.

All employees of the Water Works are required to know the locations of the emergency telephone numbers and names of individuals to contact in case of a release.  If an emergency occurs, each employee will have an assigned task.  This risk management program enhances the safety plan already in operation because it provides a clear checklist that identifies predetermined individuals and agencies that require notification and coordination.  This RMPlan details which individuals will respond to the release to stop it and it outlines the agencies that will be responsible for evacuating the appropriate areas, and for sounding the "all clear" once the leak is contained.  The plan also includes procedures for the periodic review of readiness.
The Wilako Waste Water Treatment Plant has been operational for approximately two years, and to date, there have not been any major or minor reported releases from this facility.  The primary purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to maintain the plant's cur

rent high level of safety and safety record.
    
This plan includes the following sections:
7 Program requirements
7 Hazard Assessment
7 Emergency Response
7 Prevention Plan
7 Audits
Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS), Tier 2 reports, employee training certificates and release confirmation and report forms will be maintained as part of this document.

 Section 2    Plan Requirements
Section 2.1    Introduction
Facilities that store certain chemicals in quantities that exceed a threshold quantity listed in 40 Code of Federal Register (CFR) Part 68 are required to develop and implement a Risk Management Plan (RMPlan).  Currently, the Wilako Wastewater Plant stores and uses chlorine in quantities that exceed the published threshold amount.  Anhydrous ammonia, another covered chemical is used and stored on-site, but in quantities less than the threshold quantity.  Sulfur dioxide will likely be added to the process in order to improve the water treatment capabilities of the plant in the future and the anticipated amount may exceed the threshold quantity for that chemical.

Specific requirements which must be addressed in each facility's RMPlan depends upon the program level in which it falls.  The program level determination of a facility depends on several factors, including off-site consequence and coverage under other regulations.

Section 2.2    Program Level Determination

There are currently three program levels.  A facility will be included in Program Level 1 if it exceeds one of the threshold quantities, but does not have any off-site consequence as determined by a hazard assessment.  Program Level 2 covers those facilities that exceed a threshold quantity, has off-site consequences, but are not regulated by the Occupational Health & Safety Administrative (OSHA).  Facilities that fall into Program Level 3 are subject to OSHA regulations, exceed a threshold quantity and have potential off-site consequence or the industry has one of the specified SIC codes.  Currently municip

alities are not subject to federal OSHA regulations, and Alabama does not have a state OSHA equivalent.  The off-site consequence analysis (Reference Section 3) indicates that there could be off-site consequences if a chemical release of chlorine, anhydrous ammonia or sulfur dioxide occurred at the Wilako Wastewater Treatment Plant; therefore, the facility falls in Program Level 2.

Section 2.3    General Requirements

The regulations outline five specific requirements for program Level 2 facilities.  By June 21, 1999, each facility covered under the Risk Management Program rule must have completed and submitted to the EPA a Risk Management Plan.  The EPA has requested that all submittals be transmitted electronically on their forms with appropriate figures or maps.  For reference, a copy of the form has been attached as Attachment A.  A facility in Program Level 2 must conduct a hazard analysis, develop a prevention plan, implement an emergency response plan, and report any chemical accidents in the past five years.
 Section 3    Hazard Assessment

Section 3.1    Toxicology/Physical Properties

It is imperative that employees are informed about the physical properties and potential health hazards of the chemicals located at the facility.  Mishandling of the chemicals can lead to severe injury or even death; therefore, it is vital that information regarding the substances is available to all employees.  In addition, chemical interaction information should be made available to employees as well, since ammonia and sulfur dioxide are incompatible with one another.

Section 3.1.1    Chlorine

Chlorine is listed and regulated as an extremely hazardous chemical under Section 304 and can cause severe injury or death.  Chlorine is delivered to the Wilako Plant as liquefied compressed gas.  Chlorine gas is not explosive or flammable; however, it may support combustion.  It is a strong oxidizer and may react violently with substances such as water, ammonia, fuel oil, etc.  Chlorine gas i

s denser than air (density 2.49) and tends to settle in low areas.  It has a greenish-yellow color, and a strong pungent irritating odor with an odor threshold of approximately 3.5 ppm.  At standard temperature and pressure 1 ppm chlorine is equal to 2.76 milligrams per cubic meter in air.

The primary health hazard from chlorine exposure is damage to the respiratory system. It can also irritate the mucous membranes and targets the eyes, and skin.  In extreme cases, death by suffocation can result.  Frostbite may also occur if direct contact is made with liquefied chlorine.  The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NOISH) lists 10-ppm chlorine in air as immediately dangerous to life or health (IDLH).  NIOSH recommends a ceiling value of 0.5 ppm chlorine in air while OSHA regulations list 1.0-ppm chlorine in air as the ceiling value.

Section 3.1.2    Anhydrous Ammonia

Anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the site and stored as a liquefied compressed gas.  This chemical is also listed as an extremely hazardous substance and is reportable under Section 304.  Ammonia is a colorless gas with a pungent, suffocating odor.  Ammonia is a strong oxidizer that is corrosive to copper as well as to galvanized surfaces.  It is also either incompatible and may react with some acids.  The Department of Transportation (DOT) classifies ammonia as non-flammable; however, it should be treated as one.  Ammonia tends to rise (density is 0.771) when released into the atmosphere.  The conversion factor for converting the concentration of ammonia in ambient air is 1ppm=0.70 mg/m3. 

The primary health concern is damage to the eyes, skin and mucous membranes of the respiratory tract.  Irritations and swelling to the eyes, nose, throat are symptoms of exposure to ammonia.  Prolonged exposure to liquid or high concentrations of the vapor can cause painful, instant and possible irreversible damage to these tissues.  Depending on exposure, concentration and duration, effects vary f

nt in one-ton cylinders, and the anhydrous ammonia is stored in a 1,000-gallon above ground storage tank.  Sulfur dioxide is expected to be stored in one ton cylinders once added to the process.  The maximum fill capacity of the 1,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia tank is 4,500 pounds.

The rates of release for chlorine, anhydrous ammonia, and sulfur dioxide are 200 pounds per minute (lbs./min), 450 lbs./min, and 200 lbs./min., respectively.  The off-site consequence analysis was conducted in accordance with Chapter 4: Off-Site Consequence Analysis of the General Guidance For Risk Management Programs October 27, 1998.  The charts and tables listed in Chapter 4 were developed with the aid of the Aerial Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA) air dispersion modeling program developed by the National Safety Council (NSC).

The end point concentrations used in the model were based on the requirement of the 40 CFR Part 68.22.  The end point concentrations are based on the ERPG-2 concentrations developed by the AIHA.  The ERPG-2 concentration is defined as "the airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one (1) hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action".  The end point concentrations are as follows:

7 3 ppm or 0.0087 milligrams per liter for chlorine (mg/l)
7 200 ppm or 0.14 mg/l for ammonia
7 3 ppm for sulfur dioxide 

One of the major parameters of the ALOHA Model is the surface roughness, which in the guidance document is simplified as classifying the site as urban or rural.  In the analysis of a chlorine, release at the Wilako Wastewater Treatment Plant the site was classified as rural.  The results of the analysis were as follows:

7 3.0-mile radius for chlorine
7 3.0-mile for sulfur dioxide, 
7 1.2-mile radius circle for anhydrous ammonia.

An estimated population of 4,000 lies within

rom none to only mild irritation, to obstruction of breathing from laryngeal to bronchial spasms, to edema and severe damage to mucous membranes of the respiratory tract with possibly fatal results.  Liquefied ammonia is also extremely cold, and can cause frostbite.  The IDLH for ammonia is currently listed at 300-ppm.  OSHA currently regulates the allowable workplace air concentration at 50-ppm; however, NIOSH recommends a 25-ppm, and a ceiling concentration of 35-ppm for ammonia.

If an individual's eyes are exposed to anhydrous ammonia, the recommended first aid measure is to flush with large amounts of water for at least 15 minutes and immediately seek medical aid.  If skin is exposed to anhydrous ammonia, remove clothing, and if the clothing has frozen to the skin, thaw with water before removal and wash with soap immediately.  Since ammonia is most commonly found as a gas, ingestion is not as likely; however, if it is ingested and the victim is conscious, DO NOT induce vomiting but have him drink large quantities of water.  If inhalation occurs, and the victim has stopped breathing, administer artificial respiration or oxygen immediately.

Respiratory equipment should be selected based on evaluation of hazards and the degree of potential exposure.  A chemical cartridge respirator or self-contained breathing apparatus may be sufficient for effective respiratory protection depending on the level of exposure.

In case of an accidental release of 100-lbs or more of ammonia within 24 hours, the incident must be reported to the National Response Center (800) 424-8802, as well as other local and state agencies.  

Section 3.1.3.    Sulfur Dioxide

Sulfur dioxide is a corrosive and poisonous colorless gas with a characteristically irritating and pungent odor.  It is also regulated as an extremely hazardous substance under Section 304.  It is a nonflammable gas that reacts with water to form sulfurous acid and produce toxic and corrosive fumes.  Sulfur dioxide tends to se

ttle in low places (vapor density = 2.62).  Sulfur dioxide is typically delivered to the site as a liquefied compressed non-flammable gas.  It is either incompatible or reacts with copper, brass, aluminum and ammonia.

Sulfur dioxide can damage the upper respiratory tract and the bronchi, as it can produce respiratory paralysis.  In addition, it can irritate the eyes as well as inflame the conjunctiva.  Exposures to this chemical can be fatal.  Sulfur dioxide has a suffocating odor and can be detected at low concentrations possibly by taste rather than a sense of smell.  Sulfur dioxide can be detected by taste at a concentration of approximately 0.3-ppm, and is usually detected by odor at 3-ppm. Concentration between 6-ppm and 12-ppm can irritate the nose and throat.  100-ppm in ambient air of sulfur dioxide is considered IDLH conditions.  OSHA regulates a 5-ppm work place air concentration.  NIOSH recommend a 2-ppm concentration with a ceiling concentration of 5-ppm sulfur dioxide in air.  The conversion between ppm and mg/m3 is 1-ppm = 2.62 mg/m3.

If a person is exposed to this chemical, and experiences toxic symptoms such as the occurrence of irritation to the eyes, nose, and throat appear, they should immediately be removed to fresh air.  If the eyes are involved, they should be irrigated with large quantities of warm water.


Section 3.2 "Worst Case" Scenario

The EPA requires that for each chemical that exceeds the threshold quantity, a "worst case" scenario should be performed to determine the off-site consequence.  The EPA defines the "worst case" scenario as follows:

The largest single vessel, container or pipe that contains the chemical 
of concern releases the entire contents as a gas when full during a ten 
minute time period.
    
The definition also assumes that during the release, atmospheric conditions are a class F, ambient air temperature is 77 degrees Fahrenheit (F), and wind speed is 1.5 meters per second. 

Chlorine is delivered to the Wilako Pla

the estimated 3-mile radius as defined by the "Worst Case" scenario for chlorine and sulfur dioxide and approximately 1,000 people are included in the anhydrous ammonia area.

Section 3.3    Alternative Release Scenario

The regulations governing RMPlan's require that an alternative release scenario be performed in addition to the EPA defined "worst case" scenario.  These release scenarios consider items such as line breaks, valve failure, seal failure, vent failure, etc.  In order to provide for the highest degree of public protection, the scenario that had the highest release rate of the chemical of concern was used in the alternate release scenario.  For chlorine, the >-inch feed line was assumed to completely break near the tank.  Automatic shut-off valves are installed on the chlorine tank, but were considered to fail in this analysis.  The >-inch vent line on the anhydrous ammonia tank was assumed completely broken. It is anticipated that a >-inch feed line will be used once sulfur dioxide is added to the process.  For the alternative analysis of sulfur dioxide, it was assumed that the line would break at the tank.

The same end point concentrations that were used in this analysis as in the "worst case" scenario.  The atmospheric stability used in the alternative analysis is a class D; wind speed of 3 m/s and ambient temperature is 77 degrees F.  The analysis estimated a 1.4-mile radius for chlorine, a 0.4-mile radius for anhydrous ammonia and a 0.9-mile radius for sulfur dioxide.  This analysis also classified the site and area as rural, and the end point distances were based on the results from the ALOHA Model.  This is the same model and guidance reference used in the "worst case" scenario (Section 3.1).  The results are summarized in Table 3.1.

 Section 4    Emergency Response
   Section 4.1    Introduction
A coordinated effort is required to respond effectively, in the event that there is a release of chemicals from the site.  This plan identifies the parties as well as outlines the methods for responding.  The response must be a joint effort between the water system, city police, county sheriff department, fire department, and Hazard Material (Hazmat) team in order for it to be successful.  The water system will be responsible for either maintaining a Hazmat team or having an emergency response contractor on retainer who can respond within a reasonable time, until either the County or City Fire Department establishes a Hazmat team.

Once an alarm has been sounded, it is the water system's responsibility to first confirm the release, and then to notify the sheriff department, fire, city police department and the emergency response team if necessary.  Decision-making will be made by the Waste Superintendent and based upon the type and quantity of chemical released.

   Section 4.2    Response Procedure

It is critical to have a response procedure documented and rehearsed so that in case of an emergency, proper procedures are carefully followed.  During normal business hours, an on-site individual will be assigned as the supervisor that is responsible for implementing the plan.  The supervisor shall have thoroughly reviewed this plan emergency plan, and have detailed knowledge of the chemical hazards and their physical properties of the chemicals used at this facility.  He must also be capable of and have the authority to make the decision to either respond to the leak or evacuate the facility.  The on-site supervisor shall be responsible for contacting and notifying the required agencies and adjacent facilities.  A flow chart has been prepared and is attached as Appendix D for ease of viewing.  The chart illustrates the procedure

s to be followed once a release is suspected, and who shall be contacted.  Appendix F is a RMPlan personnel chart.  This table can be removed, reproduced and posted to identify assignments.  All employees at the wastewater plant shall be informed of the emergency procedures, their responsibilities, and shall be furnished a copy of the Release Response Flow Chart.  Maps of the excavation route, and potential impact area will be displayed on site in a location accessible and visible to all employees and the public.

Once a release is suspected, the site supervisor shall be notified immediately.  After the supervisor has been notified, he shall have an individual designated who will be responsible for notifying all of the on-site personnel of the suspected release.  All other personnel except for confirmation team shall prepare for immediate evacuation and move toward the front office.  The on-site supervisor shall designate a second person that shall accompany the supervisor during the release confirmation.  The team shall be equipped with a radio that is in contact with a third person who should be positioned at the front office.  The third person will be responsible for immediately notifying all parties in the event that the confirmation team becomes incapacitated.

Section 4.3    Agency Coordination

If a release occurs at the Wilako facility, it is critical that all agencies are fully informed of the associated risk of the chemicals stored at the facility.  Letters, maps and a copy of the Tier 2 report have been submitted to the Elmore County Sheriff Department, Wetumpka Police Department, Elmore County EMA, and Russell Mills Manufacturing.  Russell Mills has been notified that since they have a facility adjacent to the wastewater plant, and have several hundred employees that they may have to evacuate if a release occurs.  The following is a list of the agencies, telephone numbers, and contact names:

A meeting shall be conducted on-site with all appropriate agencies.  The purpose of the meeting will be to review this plan, review the list of chemicals stored on-site and their locations, discuss each agency's responsibly, and traffic flow.  At a minimum, an annual meeting should also be conducted so that any changes can be discussed.  At the meeting, each agency can review the chemical dangers and the emergency response plan.  Each agency will also be encourage to tour the plant as frequently as they feel is necessary to keep up to date and refreshed on the emergency response plan.
 
Section 4.4    Employee Training

The Wetumpka Water & Sewer Board maintains an emergency chlorine kit on-site.  At a minimum, the on-site supervisor and designated assistant shall be properly trained in the use of chlorine, dangers, and the proper use of the repair kits.  All personnel on-site involved in the wastewater process shall be trained in the use and dangers of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia.  Employee training should be conducted as recommended by the Chlorine Institute.  A copy of the "The Chlorine Manual" Edition 5, 1986 is attached in the Wilako Wastewater Treatment Safety Program.  All personnel involved with the process should review the manual.  In general, the training requirements are as follows:

1. Instruction detailing physical, chemical and toxicological properties of the chemical.
2. Instruction and drills using emergency equipment.
3. Instruction and drills using the emergency repair kits.
4. Instruction and drills implementing the emergency response plan, and administering first aid.
5. Instruction detailing reporting of releases.


Section 4.5    Community Awareness

A vital part of imple

menting an effective emergency response plan is to have community awareness and involvement.  An informed public will make an evacuation successful.  Once the RMPlan is submitted to the EPA, the information about the quantities of hazardous chemicals used at this facility and their location will be available to the public via the Internet.  In addition, it is recommended that public service notices be placed in the local paper, as well as also announced over the radio.  These notices should include information concerning how the public will be notified, the evacuation route they should take, and where further information will be disseminated.
 Section 5    Prevention Program

Section 5.1    Introduction
In the prevention program, elements such as general safety information, a hazard review, operating procedures and compliance audits are included.  Various techniques for implementing a prevention plan are already outlined in the Wilako Wastewater Treatment Safety Program.  This prevention plan includes two categories.  The first category is prevention through maintenance and the second is prevention of injury through training.  Employees should be educated by attending routine safety meetings sponsored by the Plant, attend mandatory safety education classes, and working together to make their surroundings a reminder of proper safety procedures.  This can be done by hanging visual reminders such as posters, as well as maintaining a safety suggestion box that all deal with effective methods of prevention awareness.  In addition, assigning personnel to different duties or tasks in case of an emergency, and designating personnel to be responsible for safety equipment maintenance are all vital to a successful prevention program.  The following are names and numbers that each employee should be aware of in case of an emergency and these numbers should be posted at each telephone location:

 Section 5.2    Safety Information

           Section 5.2.1    CHLORINE

Preparedness for an emergency dealing with a chlorine leak or spill is essential since chlorine accumulation magnifies rapidly in the atmosphere and once a leak is identified, immediate action must be taken.  Whenever possible, no person should work alone on a chlorine leak.  An emergency plan of action should be implemented and include training or personnel who could become involved in a chlorine related emergency.

Effective emergency response in handling chlorine leaks and spills depends on the effectiveness and competence of the employees on site who can assess a situation and act accordingly.  It is the responsibility of the supervisors to train their employees to use personal protective and other safety equipment properly.  It is also the responsibility of the supervisors to educate their employees properly handling chlorine and the dangers related to the mishandling of the chemical.  In addition, employees should participate in periodic drills to review the appropriate responses and know first aid procedures as well as who to call in case of an emergency.  These drills should include designating a person to check the chlorine monitors and wind direction indicators to determine if an evacuation is necessary, an evacuation plan, the proper safety equipment and the proper respiratory protection to wear as well as the procedure for obtaining further assistance.  The telephone numbers of the chlorine suppliers should be posted near each telephone.  

In addition, the number for the Chlorine Institute's Emergency Plan (CHLOREP) through CHEMTREC in the United States is (800) 424-9300

.  CHEMTREC is typically used to provide assistance to emergencies involving the transportation of chlorine; however, they can provide information and assistance to on-site emergencies, as well.  They will have a listing of the locations of all chlorine emergency kits available for your plant of the proper registration was done when the kits were delivered.

If a leak occurs, it may be necessary to contact local authorities to assist with evacuation.  In some instances, depending on whether there has been a "reportable quantity" leaked, some governmental agencies must be contacted for chlorine emissions.  If an evacuation is necessary, then potentially exposed persons should move to a point upwind of the leak since chlorine is heavier than air.  If evacuation seems impractical, all air conditioners and air intake systems should be turned off; and individuals should retreat to the highest point of the building on the side away from the release.  When a person is outdoors, and they do not have respiratory protection, they should cover their mouth and nose with a wet handkerchief or cloth to reduce the effects of the exposure.

Personal protection equipment should be available outside of chlorine rooms, near each use point, away from areas likely subject to contamination.  Respiratory equipment should be selected based on evaluation of hazards and the degree of potential exposure.  Canister gas masks (25 ppm, maximum) or chemical cartridge respirators (up to 10 ppm) would offer adequate protection where the oxygen content in the air is greater than 19.5%.  If there is no monitoring equipment available to sample the air in the area of the 
 leak, then a self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) with a full-face piece is recommended.

Section 5.2.2    Anhydrous Ammonia

Ammonia is most commonly found as a colorless gas or compressed liquid with an extremely pungent odor.  The most important safety issue for employees dealing with ammonia is that liquid ammonia reacts violen

tly with water.  Neither the gas nor the liquid is explosive or flammable; however, they both may react chemically with many other substances.  Although ammonia does not meet the DOT definition of a flammable gas, it should be treated as one, as it may support combustion.  There is a moderate fire hazard as well as a moderate explosion hazard when it is exposed to heat or flame.  

Section 5.3    Certifications

Each employee at the Wilako wastewater facility will be required to attend an instructional class detailing this RMPlan.  At the completion of the class, each employee will be assigned a responsibility to perform as part of the emergency response plan.  A copy of the Employee Training Certification is attached as Appendix G.  This training should be updated annually, and the certificates should be maintained as part of this document in Appendix G.

In addition, each employee involved in the chlorine process should be certified to handle and use chlorine.  This certification process is currently in effect at the Wilako wastewater plant as part of the safety program.  Each individual who holds a certification to handle chlorine should attach their certificates to the Employee Training Certificates located in Appendix G.
 
Section 6    Audits

Section 6.1    Review Schedule

This plan should be reviewed at a minimum of once a year.  If the process quantity of chlorine or anhydrous ammonia changes, then the plan should be modified at that time.  This plan is also designed to accommodate the forthcoming addition of sulfur dioxide to the system.  When sulfur dioxide is added to the system, this plan should be reviewed to ensure the predicted quantity is consistent with the actual quantity added.  If a release occurs at the facility, an investigation should be conducted immediately in order to determine the reason for the release so those steps can be taken to prevent future incidents.  The RMPlan submittal to the EPA should be updated immediately following any inventory ch

ange.  If any other chemical is added to the system, a review should be conducted to determine if it is subject to the RMPlan regulations.

Section 6.2    Training Personnel

As part of the preventive maintenance and safety program, an annual refresher-training course should be conducted.  The training should include a refresher of the RMPlan, which includes the safety program, prevention program, and emergency response.  As part of the safety program, a review of chemical hazards, use and maintenance of the safety equipment, and use of the emergency repair kits should be completed.  In addition, those individuals assigned to a respirator should be fit tested.  The person conducting the training should be familiar with the use and hazards of chlorine, up to date on OSHA regulations, and knowledgeable of personal protective equipment.  GM&CE recommends that the person conducting the training is a certified Industrial Hygienist.

Section 6.3    Reporting

Chlorine, anhydrous ammonia, sulfur dioxide, and phosphoric acid are all subject to release reporting under the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA), and the Comprehensive Emergency Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA).  The quantities subject to reporting are listed in Table 2.1.  The reporting threshold for chlorine is 10 pounds, anhydrous ammonia is 100 pounds, sulfur dioxide is 500 pounds, and phosphoric acid is 5,000 pounds.  The specific gravity ranges from 1.87 for pure phosphoric acid to 1.33 for a 50% solution.  Therefore, the 5,000 pounds would equate to approximately 312-gallons of pure acid, and approximately 440-gallons of 50% solution.  Any release above the threshold quantities should be reported on the Alabama Emergency Management Agency (AEMA) Form 10.  (This form can be obtained by contacting the State Emergency Management Agency).

If a release occurs, the emergency reporting number is 1-800-843-0699.
